titleStmt.title: Letter from Henry B. Amos (League for the Prohibition of Cruel Sports) to Thomas Hardy — 24 August 1926

publicationStmt.p: Unpublished autograph letter held at the Dorset History Centre / Dorset Museum, MS H.749.

support.p: Two leaves of cream wove paper, ca. 178 × 115 mm, written recto only, in blue ink. Printed letterhead upper left (page 1) on first sheet; ink slightly feathered in places. Horizontal ruled guidelines faintly visible.

layout.p: Single column of continuous text, left-aligned, with indented salutation and closer. Signature below closing formula; docketed at foot of second page in pencil.

handNote.p: Written in a quick, right-slanting cursive with large, looping ascenders. The hand is regular but energetic; spacing close; descenders often elongated. Occasional word-division errors (e.g. “any one”) and light underlining for emphasis. Ink is dark blue, applied with a fountain pen.

msDesc.note: Printed letterhead: “LEAGUE for PROHIBITION of CRUEL SPORTS” with subheadings naming officers and committee members (including Sir George Greenwood, Ernest Bell, and Henry B. Amos) and the office address “York House, Portugal Street, London, W.C.2”.
Pencil docket lower left verso: “Thomas Hardy, O.M.” (later archivist hand).

abstract.p: Henry B. Amos, Secretary of the League for the Prohibition of Cruel Sports, writes to Thomas Hardy seeking a message to be read at a forthcoming meeting condemning a stag-hunt. Amos deplores the incident, arguing that hunts escape censure while ordinary citizens are prosecuted for lesser offences involving dogs.

note.p: Henry B. Amos (fl. 1910s–1930s) was Secretary of the League for the Prohibition of Cruel Sports, an early British pressure group advocating legislation to ban blood sports. Writing from London, he sought statements of support from leading literary figures such as Thomas Hardy. Hardy, who had long expressed sympathy for animal welfare, occasionally contributed public letters or endorsements to such campaigns.

div.p:
I presume to send you the enclosed and to ask for the favour of a brief message for our meeting on Friday.
The whole district, from the Vicar, leading Councillors, and most prominent women to the poorest person, is against the disgraceful act of the Hunt driving a stag over the cliffs to instant death. But I want them to realise the enormity of the fact that whilst Hunts, with fifty dogs, get off for cruelties of this kind—

the householder is heavily fined or sent to prison if he worries a cat or sheep with his dog.
You, more than any one, can say a word that will lift the whole subject into public consideration. I hope it may be my privilege to help give wings to such a message.
